Composite (PVA/Cu nano) films: Two yield points, embedding mechanism and thermal properties
Ahmed Gamal El-Shamy Physics Department, Faculty of Science, Suez Canal University, Ismailia, Egypt
A R T I C L E I N F O
Keywords: PVA Cu nanoparticles Thermal properties Mechanical properties Embedding mechanism
A B S T R A C T
Direct embedding of Cu nanoparticles into the PVA surface is detected by AFM and a fresh embedding mechanism submitted via the change of the annealing temperatures (Tannealing). When the Tannealing goes above the glass transition temperature of PVA, Cu nanoparticles are rapidly sinked by a thin wetting layer of PVA. In order to it makes capillary pressure on a Cu nanoparticles, suggested, this wetting layer is accountable for Cu embedding. Also, study of the thermal and mechanical properties of the nanocomposites during the embedding of Cu into the PVA. The XRD patterns show that the presence of the Cu nanoparticles in the PVA matrix. The DSC studies show an increase in the glass temperature (Tg) from 344.4 K for the green PVA to 354.2 K for the annealing temperature 423 K. Also shows two melting points for the composites (PVA/Cu nano) with thermal annealing temperature below the glass temperature (Tg) and one melting point with annealing above the glass temperature (Tg). The study shows that Young’s modulus (Y) increases with increasing the thermal annealing temperatures from 0.20× 109 Pa for the green PVA to 3.75× 109 Pa for the annealing temperature 423 K. In addition to, the strength at the break increases, while the elongation at break decreases with increasing the thermal annealing temperatures.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Recently, the nanoparticles (NPs) located on the surfaces of polymer have a great concern since these systems can have extraordinary physical properties (optical, electrical, mechanical), sensing in optical, catalytic and antimicrobial activities [1–6] that can be adjusted by changing the particle structures (type, size, shape and surface functionality). To sit the nanoparticles on or near a surface of the polymer, different techniques were used for this goal, such as evaporation [1,4] and ion implantation [2,7] approaches. For example, to bring the Ag nanoparticles near the PMMA surface, the ion implantation approach was used. In another example, the thermal evaporation method was utilized, for Bi, Sn, In, Au, Pb, and Ag metals, to make the nanoparticles arrays and metal nanowires on the surfaces of PMMA or PS of (PS-bPMMA) having a morphology with a cylindrical shape [1,8]. The thermal decomposition method has also been used to segregate the Ag nanoparticles from the polymer surface, producing polymer surfaces with highly conducting and/or reflective properties [9–12]. In the same context, more recently the gamma irradiation was used to segregate the Ag nanoparticles from the PVA surface, el-shamy et al. [13]. Directly from the solution, the nanoparticles were deposited onto a surface to modify the surface of the polymer [14–17]. Nanoparticles brought near the surface affect both the block copolymers morphology properties and
the properties of the surface, too. For example, the semiconductor CdSe nanoparticles was segregated to the P2VP surface of the films (PS-bP2VP), due to their low surface energy that enhanced the alteration of the P2VP cylinders orientation from parallel to perpendicular aligns with respect to the Si substrate [18]. More interest study, the Ag nanoparticles, segregated from the surface, were set up to ease up the transition from perpendicular lamellae to parallel one close the PS-bPMMA film surface [19]. In most of these experiments, the morphology properties of the surface of the copolymer block depend on where the precise location of nanoparticle that can be either, the surface embedded or partially embedded (exposed at the surface). To exactly adjust the properties of the polymer surface nanocomposite films, it is necessary to know how the interaction between the nanoparticles and the surface of a melt done and how they embedded into and below the surface. The films of polymer nanocomposite are perfect systems for discovering the fundamental principles of thermodynamic that rule embedding of nanoparticle into a polymer surface. The complete nanoparticle embedding into a melt polymer was shown by Kovacs et al., and is predicted if γ1> γ 2 + γ12, where γ1 and γ 2 are the energies of the surface of the nanoparticle and polymer, respectively, and γ12 is the energy of the interface between nanoparticle and polymer. This condition is generally worked for metal nanoparticles on a polymer surface and hence complete embedding is predicted. On the other hand, this

condition may not be working for inorganic nanoparticles on a surface polymer, producing incomplete wetting or exposed nanoparticles [20,21].
Rimai et al. [22] detected the engulfment rate of (8 nm) soda-lime glass particles in a surface of PS by using SEM and after several months, showed that the particles were partially exposed. Forrest et al. [23,24] observed the implanting of (10, 20 nm) of Au nanoparticles can be used to investigate the Tg close the PS surface by using SPM microscopy and found that as compared to the bulk, the (Tg)surface is very low. On the other hand, McKenna et al. [25] indicated that the embedding rate of Au nanoparticles in the surface of PS may be illustrated by the mechanics of viscoelastic contact without invoking a depression of the (Tg)surface. Other team work has used XPS and X-ray reflectivity spectroscopy [26–29] to detect the implanting of metal nanoparticles on surfaces of polymer and, thus, the (Tg)surface. But some reports show full embedding of metal nanoparticles, some show only partial/incomplete embedding mechanism, resulting in exposed nanoparticles on the surfaces of polymer [20–24,27,28]. According to the fact that the metal nanoparticles embedding depends on “mobility of chains” of the polymer, so at T< Tg the incomplete or no embedding can be predicted, whereas a complete embedding of nanoparticles is detected at T> Tg [28]. By using the solvent annealing, embedding of nanoparticle can also be tempted when the film directed to a saturated solvent vapor [20]. Although some reports on embedding of nanoparticle have been done using a variety of methods, the mechanism of the nanoparticles embedding remains mysterious.
We think that there are no reports on the embedding of Cu nanoparticles into the polymer matrix, and this is may be due to the oxidation of the Cu when located on the surface of the polymer and exposed to air. Here, we think that this is the first paper on the embedding mechanism of the Cu nanoparticles and, also on the study of the thermal and mechanical properties of the nanocomposites during the embedding of Cu into the PVA.

sections.heading: 2. Experimental
sections.text:
The polyvinyl alcohol (Mw=125,000 g/mole, polydispersity index: PDI= 0.25), copper nitrate (Cu(NO3)2.6H2O, 99.8% purity) and ascorbic acid (99.7%) used here to prevent the copper oxidation, were purchased from the Sigma–Aldrich Chemicals.
The green PVA film was prepared by the casting method as follows [29]: PVA powder was dissolved in bidistilled water at 338 K with stirred by using magnetic stirrer, thoroughly for 2 h until the mixture was completely dissolved. The solution was poured into a flat glass plate dish. Homogeneous films were obtained after drying in an air for average 5 days.
The composite (PVA/Cu nano) films were prepared by in-situ chemical reduction method [30,31]. composite (PVA/Cu nano) with 0.5 wt % of copper was prepared by dissolving copper nitrate in 5mL of bidistilled water at room temperature and 1.5 g of PVA in 50mL of the bidistilled water. The temperature of PVA solution was kept at 338 K for 2 h. When the PVA becomes completely dissolved, the copper nitrate solution was added drop-by-drop using a burette at constant 338 K in the presence of ascorbic acid to prevent the oxidation of copper. The process of the in-situ mechanism involves a chemical dispersion of Cu ion from copper nitrate in polyvinyl alcohol and in-situ Cu+ → Cu reduction-reaction with active PVA molecules under hot conditions (with mechanical stirring) at temperature 338 K. The product results in a metal Cu-polyvinyl alcohol complex, dispersed in the solution (in hot conditions at 338 K). After evaporating part of water, a derived viscous solution is casted. In addition to, active OH-groups (free from Hbonding) in polyvinyl alcohol molecules of refreshed surfaces act as head groups to adsorb Cu+ and drive a directional Cu+ → Cu growth. The addition of copper nitrate solution to the polymer solution turns the reaction mixture to a dark brown color. The solution is simply poured into a Petri-dish, and the solvent is allowed to evaporate for an average
5 days at room temperature. The prepared films are then separated from the Petri dishes. Thickness of the prepared films was measured using digital caliper and found to be 210 μm. The atomic absorption spectroscopy (AA) was performed for the contents of the copper and was found to be 0.5 wt.%.

sections.heading: 2.1. Instruments and method
sections.text:
Crystal structures of as prepared composites (PVA/Cu nano) were conducted by X-ray diffraction (X-ray, D/Max 2200 V, Rigaku, Japan) with ∝CuK =λ nm( 0.15406 ) radiation at room temperature.
The surface morphology of the nanocomposite films was showed by atomic force microscopy, AFM was operated in contact mode using nonconductive silicon nitride probe, manufactured by Bruker. Model:MLCT-MT-A. The AFM measurements were carried out in air. The scanning area of the films was (5× 5) μm2. Software (proscan 1.8) was used for controlling the scan parameters.
Thermal analysis was performed using differential scanning calorimetry (DSC-60 Shimadzu) under nitrogen (20mL/min). Experiments were performed from the room temperature to 553 K at heating rate 10 K/min.
The stress–strain measurements were performed using a mechanical test machine (AMETEK) in which a force gauge (Hunter spring Accu force II, 0.01 N resolution) is attached to the test machine. The reading was automatically recorded through a microprocessor as a function of time. A locally made device with a motor with Microswitch system was attached to the test machine to control the strain rate. The strain rate throughout the experiment was 0.04 cm/s. The samples used in mechanical measurements were strips of dimensions (20× 2 × 021mm) of films.

sections.heading: 3.2. Stress–strain behavior
sections.text:
Fig. 2, shows the stress–strain behaviors of the green PVA and the composite (PVA/Cu nano) with and without the thermal annealing temperature.
The stress/strain curve of the green PVA can be divided into many stages, actually four stages, under the action of the tensile stress. The first stage has a linear behavior and called the recovery stage and obeys to the Hook's law. The second stage is called yield point or the neck region. The third stage is called plastic region or the deformation region, where the PVA is not able to recover to its original shape. It's known that, the green PVA is partially crystalline polymer composed of amorphous chains (tie molecules) which linked the lamellas of folded chains (crystalline layers) with each other. Under the action of the tensile stress (deformation force) that applied to the sample. The amorphous tie chains elongates, lamellar chain folds leaning or tilting, the crystalline block segments segregate and separate and the block segments and tie chains orient with tensile axis. The fourth stage is called the rupture region, where the samples fracture with increasing the tensile stress that applied to the samples.
The figure showed that, just as the Cu inserted in the PVA, composite (PVA/Cu nano), the Young modulus and the strength at break increase, and the strain at break decreases. The increase in Young modulus may be attributed to the increase in the intra-intermolecular forces between the Cu and PVA chains in the samples [31].
In addition to, its clearly show that two yield points (Upper yield point Y) and (Lower yield point P). This type of behavior is also known as a yield point phenomenon or discontinuous yielding. The cause for this behavior is the existence of interstitial atoms like Cu on the surface of the PVA. The dislocations, which are seen to be the movement of plastic deformation, are pinned to these interstitial solutes and hence become immobile. Besides, with the beginning of the plastic deformation there is an increment in the number of dislocations. This leads to the high population of dislocations and the movements of the same dislocations are restricted and cause the yield point phenomenon as shown in Fig. 2. Where the temperatures below the Tg, the molecular chains do not acquire enough thermal energy to permit them to move around. The molecules of PVA are closed into a rigid amorphous structure due to the length of chain is short, molecular groups branching off the chain and interlocking with each other, or due to the backbone structure is a rigid. So, the Cu nanoparticles are located on the surface of the PVA and not able to sink or embed in the matrix of PVA.
The mechanical parameters such as the young's modulus, tensile strength and the elongation at break were calculated as depicted below in Table 2.
However, with increasing the annealing temperature, 393 and 423 K, on the composite (PVA/Cu nano), it's found that the Young modulus and the strength at break increase, and the strain at break decreases. Also, the increase in Young modulus may discuss on the basis of the increase in the intra-intermolecular forces between the Cu and PVA chains as the annealing temperature rises.
Also, the yield points disappeared completely with increasing the annealing temperature. This may be due to, the higher annealing temperature (393 and 423 K) is larger than the glass temperature of the composite (PVA/Cu nano). The molecules of PVA acquire thermal energy that it's enough to facilitate the motion of the chains and produce a flexible structure and increase the viscosity of the composite and facilitate the sink and embedding the Cu nanoparticles from the surface of the PVA to the matrix.
Also figure shows that a shift in the neck point to lower strain these may be attributed to the idea of entering/embedding the Cu nanoparticles in PVA matrix and increasing the number of intra-intermolecular forces causing the composite (PVA/Cu nano) more crystalline than the green PVA.

sections.heading: 3.3. Surface topology
sections.text:
Fig. 3, shows the AFM images of the composite (PVA/Cu nano) before the thermal annealing treatment. It's clear that, the Cu nanoparticles are like a close stacking ball and located with high density on
the surface of the PVA films. This is may be due to the thermal annealing temperature 333 K is very near close to the glass temperature of the nanocomposites, which facilitates the moving of the PVA layers over each other. This is done during the transformation of the PVA structure from the amorphous state to the crystalline state. This transformation and the motion of layers make some line cracks and defects that covered/embedded the Cu nanoparticles in it.
By increasing the thermal annealing temperature above the glass temperature (369 K), it was clearly observed that the number of Cu nanoparticles on the PVA surface was decreased and there are some holes and bowl-shaped depression (craters) formed on the surface of the PVA. This is due to the raising of the thermal annealing temperature above the glass temperature; this raises the motion of the chain layers of the PVA. This higher thermal energy leads to the breaking of some chemical bonds and produce degradation in PVA by the displacement of the atoms. At the same time the temperature of the Cu nanoparticles were increased and a craters and holes in the PVA producing via this thermal energy because of the Cu outflow from the hot molten zones of the cascade of Cu atoms.
After the thermal annealing temperature reach to 423 K, this thermal annealing temperature induced a local melting in the PVA, and the Cu dewetting from the PVA surface and completely embedding into the PVA matrix.

sections.heading: 3.4. Thermal properties
sections.text:
The thermal behavior of the composite (PVA/Cu nano) was studied using DSC apparatus from room temperature to 553 K and the observed thermograms are shown in the Fig. 4. The figure shows two endothermic peaks for the green PVA and multiple peaks for the system (PVA/Cu nano) with and without thermal annealing. Using the thermograms, the observed first transition around 340–348 K was attributed to the glass temperature (Tg) of the structural relaxation process resulting from a kinetically phenomenon (the micro-Brownian motion of the main chain backbone). Accordingly the transition at 376.3–429.6 K for all samples was attributed to the α-relaxation (Tα) associated with the crystalline region. The endothermic peak around 426.6–450.3 K was assigned to the melting temperature Tm1, which indicates the semicrystalline nature of the green PVA.
Fig. 4, shows that the position of Tg for the green PVA films and different annealing temperature films was shifted slightly toward higher temperatures with respect to the green PVA Table 3, suggests the increasing in the thermal stability. Therefore, the Cu nanoparticles are greatly affected the PVA structure.
From the figure, the shift in Tg and Tα might be due to the effect of the annealing temperature on the crystallinity, and microstructure of the sample. It is known that, the changes in the crystalline structure and morphology affect the magnitude and position of the α-relaxation process of the PVA. Hence, it is expected, Tα could be depended on the density and perfection of the crystal packing and depended on the crystal thickness and, therefore, their Tα values. From the figure, the magnitude and shift in Tg and Tα of the samples may be due to increasing the crystal packing and increasing the chain density of the polymer by increasing the thermal annealing temperature related to the change in the peak position of XRD graph.
The increase in the crystallinity of the nanocomposite after the thermal annealing can be described as a following: Only if the Gibbs free energy U + PVeTS is lowered, the crystallization will take place. This is more likely the lower the internal energy, U, can be obtained if the chains can pack closely together to give many van der Waals interactions or if specific (usually hydrogen-bonding) intermolecular bonding can take place. In the crystal, a prediction of the likely shape of individual polymer molecules can be made by realising that, in the absence of intermolecular (or other strong intermolecular bonding) hydrogen bonding, the molecule shape of the crystal is likely to be very similar to one that would give the isolated molecule a low energy.
A loose kind of bond that is largely electrostatic in nature is the hydrogen bond and the strength of the hydrogen bond lies somewhere between that of the covalent bond and the weak attractive van der Waals forces that are exerted by different neutral molecules when they come within about a molecular radius of each other. It is usually necessary to have a eOeH or an > NeH group, i.e. a hydrogen atom attached to a small electronegative (O or N) atom to form the hydrogen bond. In nature, these bonds are strongly polar, with the H atom positive, which attracted to a negatively polarized O or N atom in the vicinity:

The effective fractional charges indicated by the symbols δ1 and δ2 and the H-bond represents by the dotted line (…….) and formed by the attraction of the hydrogen (positively charged) H atom and the oxygen (negatively charged) O atom. From the above factors for many polymers that have all-carbon backbones are the all-trans planar zigzag, the result is that the most likely (lowest-energy) conformation.
From the Gibbs free energy U + PV – TS, the composite (PVA/Cu nano) films have the lowest energy (U). So the Gibbs free energy goes to
lower values. Therefore, the composite (PVA/Cu nano) films have large crystallinity (more crystalline) for the thermal annealing samples 333, 363, 393 and 423 K.
But when the temperatures of the thermal annealing reach to (393 and 423 K), the Cu nanoparticles goes to embed in thed-spacing of the (PVA), where the crystals go packing closed together (increasing packing) making lower internal energy (U). Where the Gibbs free energy U + PV – TS is lowered and then increasing the crystallinity then increasing the melting point (Tm) of the composite (PVA/Cu nano) films.

sections.heading: 3.5. Embedding mechanism
sections.text:
The observing behavior of the embedding of Cu nanoparticles in the PVA is attributed to the thermodynamic phenomena (i) the Driving forces, and (ii) the PVA surface energy and the interaction energy between the PVA and Cu nanoparticles (interface energy).
According to the physics of thermodynamics, the Cu nanoparticles are not thermodynamically stable, when it was sited on the PVA surface and have a tendency to react, to be stable via one mechanism, (i)
Wetting mechanism or (ii) Embedding mechanism. When the system (PVA/Cu nano) has a higher surface energy of the PVA matrix as compared to that of the Cu nanoparticle located on its surface, wetting mechanism ensues. In contrast, when the system (PVA/Cu nano) has a higher surface energy of the Cu as compared to that of the PVA matrix, embedding mechanism ensues, (Cu nanoparticles have a tendency to drive in/embed into the PVA matrix). The embedding of Cu inside surface of PVA must be depend on the basis of the thermodynamic physics, mainly the driving force that controls the migration/driving of Cu through the PVA surface. It's known that when the Cu embedded from the PVA surface into the matrix, its surface Gibbs free energy when the Cu is located inside the matrix becomes lower than that when it is located on the PVA surface, agreeing to this basic, the driving force for the embedding Cu creates. In contrast, when the Cu is located on the PVA surface, Cu nanoparticles have surface Gibbs free energy higher than the surface Gibbs free energy of the PVA because the Cu nanoparticles have cohesive energy higher than the cohesive energy of the of PVA. In addition to the principle condition for producing the thermodynamic driving force is, when the system (PVA/Cu nano) has the ability or a tendency to lower this surface energy. The thermodynamic performance of Cu when located on the surfaces of PVA has been expected and expressed in equation for embedding of Cu nanoparticles. When the Cu nanoparticle, with (σ) represents the surface area of Cu, is located on the surface of PVA, its surface Gibbs free energy can be expressed as: [29]

Under some conditions such as irradiation or annealing, Only one mechanism can occurs, either the Cu wetting or the Cu dewetting when the Cu metal on the PVA surface and also related to its ability to interact with the PVA surfaces (reactive or unreactive). Also, the weakness of the interaction of the Cu with the PVA and the extremely lower free energy of the Cu surface when reducing it to obtain the stability tend to dewet the Cu from the PVA surface which producing the Cu nanoparticles. It can be shown that under the annealing temperature, the Cu nanoparticles have a high tendency to aggregate on the surface of PVA. Due to the high cohesive energy of the Cu, this leads to dewetting the PVA from its surface and produced the Cu nanoparticles on the surface. As a result, the predictable energy of the interfacial of the PVA and Cu is lower than the surface energy of the produced Cu, and gets migrated/ embedded Cu into the surface of PVA with extra annealing temperature because of the kinetic driving forces (capillary) and annealing temperature tempted viscous flow in PVA film. The migration of atoms Cu by thermal annealing temperature into the PVA matrix producing clusters of Cu in the nanoscale, and this behavior creates optical properties with functional application devices. In our case, thermal annealing has been used to embed the Cu into PVA. Also, the composite (PVA/Cu nano) was fabricated by in-situ chemical
reduction, and then directed to thermal annealing temperature from 60 to 150 °C, where nanoparticles (Cu) were distributed in the matrix of PVA and wrapped with PVA chains and become isolated from each other (Fig. 5).
The thermal annealing at high temperature (423 K) possesses a high thermal energy, which leads to breaking of some chemical bonds and degradation or by the displacement of the atoms. A result of this chemical alteration in the PVA, the atoms of Cu that located on the PVA surface lose electrons, and then (Cu°) created via the interaction of the activated OH group in PVA and the Cu+ ions. Mainly, the atoms of Cu may react with the radicals of PVA or participate in the oxidation reaction. However, the (CueCu) bonding is energetically more superior, because of a great discrepancy in Gibbs free energy (ΔGs) between the atoms of PVA and the atoms Cu. Hence, the producing of the Cu clusters inside the matrix of PVA. This is due to the Cu nanoparticles has a huge energy of cohesive and also due to the low interaction energy between the chains of PVA and the nanoparticles Cu.
Fig. 3, shows the AFM images of the composite (PVA/Cu nano) with and without the thermal annealing. Obviously, it can be shown that, at first the Cu located on the PVA surface film, the nanostructuring of the Cu constructed and also the Cu embeding in PVA matrix happens via the thermal annealing energy. This thermal annealing induced a local melting in the PVA, via the high thermal energy and a bowl-shaped depression creation (crater) which is a key factor for the Cu dewetting from the PVA surface. But with performed the thermal energy, the mixing between the phases produce (interface mixing) and the decomposition of the PVA chains at the surface that yield the Cu nanoparticles creation at the surface and the Cu embedded. Thermal spike created, the temperature of Cu metal raises and a craters and holes in the PVA producing via the thermal energy because of the Cu outflow from the hot molten zones of the cascade of Cu atoms. The size of the induced molten zone that is responsible for the dewetting process was determined by the PVA melting point (Tm). The higher surface energy of Cu than the surface energy of PVA permits the Cu out flow from the molten zones and also facilitates the Cu dewetting from the PVA surface through the process of thermal annealing.
The schematic diagram for the synthesis and embedding of the Cu nanoparticles inside the matrix of PVA was shown in (Fig. 5).
Using the thermal annealing with high thermal energy, the composite (PVA/Cu nano) has been synthesized by creating the Cu
nanoparticles via thermal energy on the PVA surface, which produces the Cu nanoparticles embedded in the matrix of PVA.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusion
sections.text: Successfully, the composite (PVA/Cu nano) films were prepared by the chemical reduction method. DSC studies showed that the glass temperature (Tg) of the composite (PVA/Cu nano) increased with increasing the thermal annealing temperature from (333 to 423 K). This is due to the quantum confinement effects of the Cu nanoparticles. The melting point and the crystallinity of the nanocomposite films were increased with increasing the thermal annealing temperature. This is attributed to the increase in the intramolecular and intermolecular interactions in the polyvinyl alcohol structure. Dramatically, incorporation/Embedding of Cu nanoparticles enhanced the mechanical properties of the nanocomposite. The tensile strength, Young’s modulus as well as increased significantly compared with pure PVA. This is due to the increase in the crosslinking inside the nanocomposite, with the increase of thermal annealing temperature. The embedding of the Cu nanoparticles into the PVA matrix was strongly depended on the thermal annealing temperature. Finally, the improvement of the thermal and mechanical properties of the composites creates an opportunity to be used in hydrothermal environment application.

metadata.abstractText: Direct embedding of Cu nanoparticles into the PVA surface is detected by AFM and a fresh embedding mechanism submitted via the change of the annealing temperatures (Tannealing). When the Tannealing goes above the glass transition temperature of PVA, Cu nanoparticles are rapidly sinked by a thin wetting layer of PVA. In order to it makes capillary pressure on a Cu nanoparticles, suggested, this wetting layer is accountable for Cu embedding. Also, study of the thermal and mechanical properties of the nanocomposites during the embedding of Cu into the PVA. The XRD patterns show that the presence of the Cu nanoparticles in the PVA matrix. The DSC studies show an increase in the glass temperature (Tg) from 344.4 K for the green PVA to 354.2 K for the annealing temperature 423 K. Also shows two melting points for the composites (PVA/Cu nano) with thermal annealing temperature below the glass temperature (Tg) and one melting point with annealing above the glass temperature (Tg). The study shows that Young’s modulus (Y) increases with increasing the thermal annealing temperatures from 0.20× 10 Pa for the green PVA to 3.75× 10 Pa for the annealing temperature 423 K. In addition to, the strength at the break increases, while the elongation at break decreases with increasing the thermal annealing temperatures.
